onboarding.label: Organization Name
onboarding.meaning: The official legal name of your company, division, or team that will use this system
onboarding.guidance: Use the name that appears on official documents. This is visible to all users.

onboarding.label: Invite Senior Managers
onboarding.meaning: Email addresses of decision-capable managers who will receive approval requests and announcements
onboarding.guidance: Add only managers with authority to make business decisions. Add more anytime from Settings. Separate by comma or newline.

onboarding.label: Default Operating Mode
onboarding.meaning: How strictly the system enforces approval workflows and audit requirements
examples: Executive Fast Lane: Quick approvals, lighter documentation
Strict Compliance: All decisions logged, formal audit trail
onboarding.guidance: Choose based on your industry. You can change this later in Admin Config.
anti_patterns: Choosing wrong mode and not updating after learning system

onboarding.label: Send First CEO Announcement?
onboarding.meaning: Whether to publish a welcome message to your team immediately after setup
examples: Yes: 'Welcome to our new request system'
No: skip for now, send later from dashboard
onboarding.guidance: Good practice: send a brief welcome. Sets tone for system usage.
anti_patterns: Using technical jargon in welcome message

onboarding.label: I acknowledge the Request Constitution
onboarding.meaning: Agreement that you understand the system's decision rules, status lifecycle, and audit guarantees
examples: Checked: You understand requests go DRAFT → SUBMITTED → APPROVED/REJECTED
onboarding.guidance: Read the attached constitution summary before checking. It's a 2-minute read.

onboarding.label: Admin Email Address
onboarding.meaning: Email of the person who will manage system configuration (you, typically)
onboarding.guidance: This account gets CEO role and config access. You can invite others to admin later.
anti_patterns: Entering wrong email and being locked out

onboarding.label: Organization Timezone
onboarding.meaning: Your timezone, used to display all timestamps in your local time
onboarding.guidance: Select your primary office timezone. All reports and timestamps convert to this.
anti_patterns: Selecting UTC when you don't work in UTC
Forgetting to change if you relocate

request_form.label: What are you requesting?
request_form.meaning: A short, clear description of what you need approval for (not details—just the headline)
examples: Launch beta feature to 10% of users
request_form.guidance: Be specific but concise. CEO should understand the ask in 5 seconds. Use object + action format.

request_form.label: Provide details and context
request_form.meaning: Detailed explanation of your request, including background, options considered, and recommended approach
examples: We've had 3 urgent customer complaints this week about feature X. Recommend fixing in hotfix.
Q2 budget proposal: $500K for new team, broken down as: 3x engineers ($150K), 1x designer ($50K)...
request_form.guidance: 2-3 paragraphs max. Use bold for key numbers. Include 'Why now?' and 'What happens if we don't?'
anti_patterns: Leaving blank (CEO won't know what to do)
Writing a novel (CEO won't read it)

request_form.label: Priority
request_form.meaning: How urgently this request needs a decision. Selected from CEO-configured labels (P1 Blocker → P5 Trivial)
examples: P1 (Blocker): System down, customer impact, decision needed today
P3 (Medium): Standard request, decision in 1-2 days
request_form.guidance: Be honest about urgency. P1 for true blockers only. CEO gets notified based on priority.

request_form.label: Category
request_form.meaning: What type of request this is (e.g. Hiring, Budget, Product, Operations). Used for sorting and filtering.
request_form.guidance: Pick the best fit. CEO can add more categories in Admin Config.

request_form.label: Upload supporting documents
request_form.meaning: Files (PDF, images, spreadsheets) that provide evidence or detail for your request
request_form.guidance: Max 10 MB per file, max 5 files. Include file name that is descriptive.
anti_patterns: Uploading files with generic names like 'Document1.pdf'

request_form.label: Who should follow this request?
request_form.meaning: Team members who will be notified of status updates and decisions, even if not involved in approval
request_form.guidance: Add people who need to know the outcome. Requester and CEO are automatic.

approval.label: Approve or Reject?
approval.meaning: Your (CEO's) final decision on the request. Approve = green light to execute. Reject = request denied.
examples: Approve: Request approved. Proceed with hiring. Start Monday.
Reject: Denied. Budget year already committed. Discuss next quarter.
approval.guidance: Be clear and decisive. Requester sees this immediately. No ambiguity.

approval.label: Add notes for the requester (optional)
approval.meaning: Optional explanation of your decision, next steps, or conditions. Visible to requester and watchers.
examples: Approved. Budget approved for Q2. Work with Finance on schedule.
Rejected. Similar proposal was made 2 months ago. Let's revisit after that ship date.
approval.guidance: Keep brief. If complex, send executive message for deeper discussion.

admin_config.label: Max Attachment Size (MB)
admin_config.meaning: Maximum file size per attachment upload (5, 10, 20, or 50 MB)
examples: 50 MB: Video engineering teams, large PDFs
admin_config.guidance: Larger files = slower uploads. Balance user need with system performance.

admin_config.label: Auto-Cancel Drafts After (Days)
admin_config.meaning: Number of days before system auto-cancels draft requests that were never submitted
admin_config.guidance: Prevents database clutter. Drafts auto-cancel by default, but requester can restore.

admin_config.label: Restore Window (Days)
admin_config.meaning: Number of days after soft-delete that a request can still be restored by requester
examples: 7 days: Quick restore, audit cleanup fast
admin_config.guidance: Provides safety net. After window, data is hard-deleted per audit retention.

admin_config.label: Default Priority Code
admin_config.meaning: Which priority level is pre-selected when manager creates a new request (P1-P5)
examples: P3 (Medium): Most requests are medium priority
P4 (Low): Only mark urgent things as high
admin_config.guidance: Set to the most common priority. Requester can override per request.
anti_patterns: Mismatching label to your actual default

admin_config.label: Who can be @mentioned by default?
admin_config.meaning: Whether @mentions are limited to request stakeholders or open to entire organization
examples: Org-wide: Any user can mention any other user
admin_config.guidance: Default scope prevents spam @mention alerts. CEO can override per request.
anti_patterns: So restricted users can't loop in relevant people

admin_config.label: Email Notification Frequency
admin_config.meaning: How often users receive email notifications (instant, daily digest, or off)
examples: Daily Digest: One email per day, summary of all events
admin_config.guidance: Instant = best for critical requests. Digest = less email noise.
anti_patterns: Off for urgent requests (users might miss them)

admin_config.label: Require acknowledgement on Urgent announcements?
admin_config.meaning: Whether users must explicitly acknowledge receipt of 'Urgent' announcements
examples: Yes: Users must click 'I acknowledge' to confirm they saw it
No: Read-only tracking, no confirmation required
admin_config.guidance: Yes = ensures critical messages are noticed. No = less friction.
anti_patterns: Required acknowledgement on low-priority items (busy users ignore)
No acknowledgement on critical stop-work orders

concepts.description: Standard pattern for every request: Create (draft), Read (view), Update (edit), Delete (soft-delete), Submit (business transition).
concepts.visual_explanation: DRAFT → (user edits) → SUBMITTED → (CEO decides) → APPROVED/REJECTED → CLOSED
rules: Every new request starts as DRAFT (no audit trail, no CEO notification yet)
User can edit/delete draft anytime
SUBMIT triggers CEO notification and approval queue
CEO can only approve/reject submitted requests
After decision, request is archived (CLOSED) or can be resubmitted if rejected
Soft-delete is orthogonal: can be undone within 7-day restore window

key_terms.Create: New request, DRAFT status, no notifications
key_terms.Update: Edit request while in DRAFT or after rejection
key_terms.Delete: Soft-delete (reversible, audit trail kept), CEO can hard-delete
key_terms.Submit: Transition DRAFT → SUBMITTED, trigger CEO notification

concepts.description: Two independent mechanisms: soft-delete is access control (reversible), cancel is business decision (terminal).
concepts.visual_explanation: Soft-Delete (deleted_at field): Access control, reversible. Cancel (status_code='CANCELLED'): Business decision, terminal.
rules: Soft-Delete: Requester or CEO can hide a request by setting deleted_at timestamp
Soft-Delete is reversible: within 7 days, anyone with access can restore
Cancel: Only valid status transition when request is in DRAFT, SUBMITTED, or IN_REVIEW
Cancel is terminal: once cancelled, request cannot be resubmitted
They are independent: a cancelled request can be soft-deleted separately
Use soft-delete for accidents. Use cancel for business decision (e.g., 'we're not hiring')

key_terms.deleted_at: Timestamp when soft-deleted, null if not deleted
key_terms.Reversible: Can undo soft-delete, cannot undo cancel
key_terms.Access Control: Soft-delete hides from view, cancel is a decision

concepts.description: Decision tree to help managers select the right priority level for their request.
concepts.visual_explanation: P1 (Blocker) → System down OR customer-blocking → P2 (High) → Team blocked OR deadline urgent → P3 (Medium) → Normal work, standard pace → P4 (Low) → Nice to have, no rush → P5 (Trivial) → Cosmetic or deferred
rules: P1 (Blocker): System down, customer impact, decision needed TODAY
P2 (High): Team blocked or deadline within 24-48 hours
P3 (Medium): Normal work, needs decision within 1 week (DEFAULT)
P4 (Low): Nice-to-have, no business impact, flexible timeline
P5 (Trivial): Cosmetic improvements, can be indefinitely deferred
Do not abuse P1. Overuse dilutes signal and trains CEO to ignore urgency.

concepts.description: Complete state diagram showing all valid status transitions for a request.
concepts.visual_explanation: DRAFT (editable) → SUBMITTED (awaiting CEO) → IN_REVIEW (CEO reviewing) → APPROVED or REJECTED → CLOSED (archived)
rules: DRAFT: Initial state, user can edit/delete, no notifications
SUBMITTED: User submitted, CEO notified, user cannot edit without rejection
IN_REVIEW: CEO is actively reviewing (optional, implicit in approval process)
APPROVED: CEO approved, request is executed, auto-archive (CLOSED)
REJECTED: CEO rejected, requester can edit and resubmit
CANCELLED: Terminal state, cannot transition to any other state
CLOSED: Request is archived and read-only
Material edits (title/priority/category) after submission trigger approval invalidation
